faq.aboutTitleOne: What is Scratch, and what can I do with it?
faq.aboutBodyOne: Scratch is a programming language and online community where you can create your own interactive stories, games, and animations -- and share your creations with others around the world. In the process of designing and programming Scratch projects, young people learn to think creatively, reason systematically, and work collaboratively. To learn more about Scratch, check out the About Scratch page.
faq.aboutTitleTwo: How do I make a game or animation with Scratch?
faq.aboutBodyTwo: Check out the help page to see lots of ways to get started with Scratch. Or just dive in to the project editor.
faq.aboutTitleThree: What are the system requirements for Scratch?
faq.aboutBodyThree: To run Scratch 2, you need a relatively recent web browser (Chrome 35 or later, Firefox 31 or later, or Internet Explorer 9 or later) with Adobe Flash Player version 10.2 or later installed. Scratch 2 is designed to support screen sizes 1024 x 768 or larger. If your computer doesnâ€™t meet these requirements, you can try downloading and installing Scratch 1.4, which you can still use to share projects to the Scratch 2 website.
faq.aboutTitleFour: Do you have a downloadable version so I can create and view projects offline?
faq.aboutBodyFour: The Scratch 2 offline editor (beta version) is now available. You can also still use Scratch 1.4.Note: You can have both Scratch 1.4 and 2 on your computer.
